channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Fifth Round of Hostages Released as Extended Truce Appears to Hold
item.description: Hamas freed a group of 10 Israelis or dual nationals and two Thai citizens on Tuesday in exchange for 30 imprisoned Palestinians, keeping with the terms of the temporary cease-fire agreement.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Sierra Leone Announces Arrest of 14 in ‘Attempted Coup’
item.description: The West African nation has not identified the military officials and one civilian it arrested after attacks in the capital on Sunday that left 20 people dead and more than 2,000 prisoners on the loose.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Joseph Johnson
item.category: Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Residents remained on edge in Freetown, Sierra Leone, following a failed coup attempt on Sunday.

item.title: Finland to Close the Last Border Crossing With Russia for Two Weeks
item.description: Relations have deteriorated markedly since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and the Finns accuse Moscow of orchestrating a flow of migrants in retaliation for Finland joining NATO.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola
item.media:description: Border guards and a customs official checking a truck at the Raja-Jooseppi international border crossing station in northern Finland on Tuesday.

item.title: Wife of Ukraine’s Spy Chief Was Poisoned, Officials Say
item.description: Marianna Budanova, whose husband is the director of military intelligence, is recovering in a hospital, the officials said. Her husband has long accused Russia of trying to kill him.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Marianna Budanova, left, and her husband, Kyrylo Budanov, Ukraine’s military intelligence chief, at a memorial service in January.

item.title: France to Ban Smoking in Forests, on Beaches and Near Schools
item.description: A government anti-smoking plan also includes costlier cigarettes and a ban on disposable vapes. Smoking is the leading cause of avoidable deaths in France.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: An ashtray with cigarette butts at a beach in Saint-Jean-de-Luz, in southwestern France.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Wins Bid to Host World Expo 2030
item.description: Winning the rights to host the major global event is a coup for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s efforts to remake the kingdom’s international image.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Vivian Nereim
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Promoting the Riyadh Expo 2030 in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: In Canada, a Judge Sentences an Incel Killer as a Terrorist
item.description: A Toronto teenager who killed a woman in a massage business was sentenced on Tuesday to life in prison. The case was the first time gender-based violence in the country was labeled terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The massage parlor in Toronto where a 17-year-old carried out a deadly knife attack in 2020, killing one woman and seriously injuring another.

item.title: Palestinians Fleeing to Southern Gaza Face Horrors
item.description: Tens of thousands of Gazans are making the most difficult of choices, leaving their homes behind to survive.
item.dc:creator: Yara Bayoumy, Samar Abu Elouf and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: Palestinians evacuating the northern Gaza Strip on Sunday, a fraught decision.

item.title: NATO Leaders Try to Pin Down U.S. on Ukraine Aid as Republicans Waver
item.description: Continued American funding for Ukraine was a key concern for leaders in the military alliance, who met as the current allocation was running down and a Ukrainian counteroffensive appeared stalled.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near Karlivka, a village in the country’s east, last month. Russia has been seeking to capture the nearby town of Avdiivka.

item.title: Americans Love Avocados. It’s Killing Mexico’s Forests.
item.description: Illegal deforestation for avocado crops points to a blood-soaked trade with the United States involving threats, abductions and killings.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and César Rodríguez
item.media:description: Avocados are process inside the Aztecavo packing house in Uruapan. Demand for avocados has skyrocketed since Mexico began importing them to the United States.

item.title: Vietnam Is Jailing Environmentalists Who Helped It Secure Billions
item.description: The government is preparing to present its energy transition plan at the U.N. climate talks as it intensifies a crackdown on environmental advocates.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Solar panels at the Sao Mai power plant in An Giang Province, Vietnam, last year. The country has been awarded $15.5 billion in grants and loans in exchange for a commitment to renewable energy.

item.title: Can U.S.-China Student Exchanges Survive Geopolitics?
item.description: The flow of students between the countries has been a mainstay of their relationship, even when ties have soured. Now these exchanges, too, are under threat.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a college fair in Beijing organized by the American Embassy.

item.title: Russian Court Extends Detention of Evan Gershkovich
item.description: The decision means that the journalist, Evan Gershkovich, who has denied the espionage charge against him, will remain in custody until Jan. 30.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, an American journalist, before a court hearing in Moscow, in October.

item.title: In New Zealand, Maori Wardens Take a Different Approach to Crime
item.description: The strategies used by the Indigenous community policing alternative are in stark contrast to more muscular tactics pitched by the incoming government.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Cornell Tukiri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maori Wardens, a group of Indigenous volunteers, patrolling the streets to check on store owners and residents in Auckland, New Zealand.

item.title: Here Are the Statuses of 240 Israeli Hostages Taken Into Gaza on Oct. 7
item.description: Eighty-five of the roughly 240 people captured have now been released.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao and Lazaro Gamio

item.title: Freed Israeli Hostages Feel Cycles of Emotion After Captivity, Families Say
item.description: ‘Everything is just so fragile,’ said a cousin of the first two hostages freed last month.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Government of Israel, via Associated Press
item.media:description: In this photo provided by the government of Israel, Natalie Raanan, 17, left, and her mother, Judith Raanan, 59, right, are being returned to Israel on Oct. 20.

item.title: Reports Say Pope Francis Is Removing Cardinal Burke’s Vatican Home and Salary
item.description: Word of the action against Cardinal Raymond Burke came after the prelate’s increasingly pointed critiques of the reform-minded pope.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Ruth Graham
item.media:description: Cardinal Raymond Burke has been Pope Francis’ leading critic from the traditionalist wing of the Catholic Church.

item.title: Pope Francis Cancels Trip to COP28 Climate Summit After Getting Sick
item.description: Days after the pontiff was forced to slow down because of a flu, his doctors advised him to not travel to Dubai for COP28. Francis has made climate activism a hallmark of his papacy.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Pope Francis reciting the Angelus prayer on Sunday, as people watched on a large screen in St. Peter’s Square.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: What to Watch at the U.N. Climate Talks
item.description: Plus how New Zealand’s Maori Wardens keep the peace.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: A Gaza Truce Aids Both Israel and Hamas. Until the Calculus Changes.
item.description: Both Israel and Hamas are reaping benefits from the cease-fire, but as the hostage-for-prisoner exchanges continue, Israeli leaders may feel growing pressure to resume the war.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians on their way from the north of Gaza to the south passing through an Israeli checkpoint on Sunday.

item.title: Hamas Releases Fifth Group of Hostages on Tuesday: What We Know
item.description: The group of 12 hostages, most of them Israelis, is the first to be released under the extended cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov, Roni Rabin and Talya Minsberg
item.media:description: Clara Marman.

item.title: Documents Show Plan for Leader of COP28 Climate Talks to Promote Fossil Fuels
item.description: A leaked document has talking points for the president of the United Nations climate conference, who is an oil executive in the United Arab Emirates, to advance oil and gas deals.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Sultan Al Jaber heads Adnoc as well as a smaller state-owned renewables company, Masdar.

item.title: Germany to Override Debt Limit to Resolve Budget Crisis
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz pledged financial support for economic modernization and Ukraine, but will need backing for new borrowing to fill a spending gap.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Olaf Scholz, Germany’s chancellor, addressing lawmakers Tuesday. The budget crisis has threatened his three-party coalition.

item.title: C.I.A. Director Arrives in Qatar for Talks on Hostage Releases
item.description: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. head, and David Barnea, who leads the Mossad, Israel’s spy service, are scheduled to meet with officials in Qatar, which has been mediating talks between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, arrived in Doha, Qatar, on Tuesday, his second visit to the country this month in pursuit of securing the release of more hostages from Gaza.

item.title: In India, Rescue Arrives for Workers Trapped in Tunnel
item.description: After repeated mechanical setbacks, the operation turned to trained miners using manual tools to clear the final stretch of debris.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: Ambulances transporting workers who were rescued from the collapsed tunnel in Uttarkashi, India, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Has Warned Israel to Fight More Surgically in Gaza, Officials Say
item.description: American officials have told the Israelis that a major bombardment risks sparking a humanitarian crisis that overwhelms the world’s capacity to respond.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States is helping to provide a surge of humanitarian aid to Gaza during the temporary truce.

item.title: New Zealand’s New Government Says It Will Scrap Smoking Ban
item.description: The law, celebrated as a model for other countries, would have eventually made tobacco illegal.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Natasha Frost
item.media:description: New Zealand’s new prime minister, Christopher Luxon, leads a government that is the country’s most right-wing in a generation.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Palestinians walking on Monday amid buildings hit by Israeli strikes in Gaza City.

item.title: Could Longevity Drugs for Dogs Extend Your Pet’s Life?
item.description: Longevity drugs for our canine companions are moving closer to reality. They also raise questions about what it might mean to succeed.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times

item.title: Egypt Wiped Out Hepatitis C. Now It Is Trying to Help the Rest of Africa.
item.description: Effective drugs that have made the disease curable have yet to reach most of the region.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Natalija Gormalova
item.media:description: Dr. Nartey, a physician at Cape Coast Teaching Hospital, joined the Coalition of Global Hepatitis Elimination to make a plan for Ghana’s new response.

item.title: Hamas and Israel Extend Cease-Fire for 2 Days, Qatar Says
item.description: The extension, and another exchange of hostages and prisoners, raised hopes that more people would be set free and more humanitarian aid would reach people in the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg, Yara Bayoumy and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Palestinians walking on Monday amid buildings hit by Israeli strikes in Gaza City.

item.title: Palestinian Activist Ahed Tamimi Faces Indefinite Detention in Israel
item.description: She is one of the highest-profile Palestinians arrested by Israel in its post-Oct. 7 crackdown. The military has moved to keep her jailed without charge, though she could also be freed in a hostage swap.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Ahed Tamimi, who became an international symbol of Palestinian resistance as a teenager, was arrested by Israeli forces in a predawn raid earlier this month.

item.title: What We Know About Israeli Hostages Hamas Released on Monday
item.description: The group comprised women and children only, all of them taken from Nir Oz during Hamas’s attack on Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg, Traci Carl, Gaya Gupta, Katherine Rosman and Roni Rabin

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: A Deal to Extend the Gaza Truce
item.description: Plus Indonesia’s female forest rangers.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times

item.title: Women and Leadership: 7 Women Discuss Their Journeys
item.description: Leaders from around the world explained how they took their passions and concerns and turned them into action.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Rozette Halvorson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Tiffani Jenae Johnson, a pediatric emergency physician and professor at UC Davis Children’s Hospital in California, has been a leader in raising awareness within the medical community about inequities in care and outcomes for children.

item.title: Eurostar to Suspend Amsterdam to London Service for 6 Months
item.description: The no-transfer rail connection from the Dutch capital to London will close starting in June. A new terminal for Eurostar passengers is set to open at Amsterdam’s main rail station in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A Eurostar train at Amsterdam Centraal Station in 2018.

item.title: Former Coal Towns Get Money for Clean-Energy Factories
item.description: An Energy Department program designed to create jobs and manufacturing in communities reliant on fossil fuels is backing projects in West Virginia, Colorado and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demolition at Weirton Steel in West Virginia in 2018. A Boston company plans to build a plant there to produce metals for the clean energy industry.

item.title: A Three-Year Cruise Is Canceled for Lack of a Ship
item.description: Passengers will not be visiting Machu Picchu, the Pyramids of Giza or indeed be going anywhere.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Markus Scholz/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A cruise line in March announced a three-year round-the-world cruise and began signing up travelers but it had to cancel because it did not have a ship.

item.title: Warnings Emerge Over Emirati A.I. Firm G42’s Ties to China
item.description: American spy agencies have warned about the Emirati firm G42 and its work with large Chinese companies that U.S. officials consider security threats.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cristiana Couceiro; Photographs by Getty Images, Reuters, and via YouTube

item.title: After 9 Years in Limbo, Treasures From Crimea Return to Ukraine
item.description: The artifacts were on loan to a Dutch museum when Russia invaded in 2014. Ukraine argued that they must be kept out of the aggressor’s hands.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:description: A visitor looking at artifacts on display at the “Crimea: Gold and Secrets of the Black Sea” exhibition at the Allard Pierson Museum in 2014.

item.title: Trial Starts in France for Teenagers Accused of Helping Teacher’s Killer
item.description: The teacher, Samuel Paty, was beheaded by an Islamist extremist in 2020 after showing caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad to illustrate free speech. The case horrified the nation.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial portrait of Samuel Paty in 2020 at a bus stop in Conflans-Sainte-Honorine, the Paris suburb where he taught.

item.title: Biden Hopes to Alter the Trajectory of the War as Hostages Are Released
item.description: At the president’s urging, the temporary truce between Israel and Hamas was extended two more days. The challenge is what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Biden spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Sunday in efforts to extend the temporary cease-fire.

item.title: Elon Musk Meets With Netanyahu in Israel Amid Backlash Against Social Media Post
item.description: Alongside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, Mr. Musk toured an Israeli village where dozens of people were killed in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: In this handout image provided by the Israeli government, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, center, takes Elon Musk, left, on a tour of Kibbutz Kfar Aza, on Monday.

item.title: Storm Batters Southern Ukraine, Spreading Misery for Civilians and Soldiers
item.description: Violent waves stirred by hurricane-force winds threatened to tear maritime mines from their moorings in the Sea of Azov and the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Viacheslav Onyshchenko/SOPA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A snowstorm blanketed Odesa, Ukraine, on Sunday night.

item.title: Russian Women Protest Long Deployments for Soldiers in Ukraine
item.description: “Make way for someone else,” a new grass-roots movement demands as women challenge the official argument that the mobilized troops are needed in combat indefinitely.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian conscripts in the Moscow region last year. New protests against long deployments are a rare example of public displeasure with the war.

item.title: Trapped in a Tunnel for 15 Days, With No End in Sight
item.description: The effort to rescue 41 construction workers in India has faced repeated setbacks. Now the authorities are trying to drill vertically through a mountain.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: The rescue effort on Sunday outside the collapsed tunnel in India.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: A third day of hostage exchanges in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A helicopter carrying hostages released by Hamas arriving in Israel on Sunday.

item.title: Female Rangers ‘Don’t Go All Alpha Like the Men’ to Protect a Forest
item.description: Rather than take a confrontational approach with trespassers looking to farm or log in a tropical rainforest in Indonesia, teams of women rangers try dialogue first.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Ulet Ifansasti
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women rangers hugged a tree while collecting data during a forest patrol near the village of Damaran Baru, in Aceh Province, Indonesia.

item.title: U.S. Navy Rescues Central Park From Pirate Attack in Gulf of Aden
item.description: The United States says the episode is unrelated to regional tensions, though it is still investigating the firing of two missiles at the Navy ship involved in the rescue.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The Central Park, a chemical tanker, in an undated photo released by Zodiac Maritime, a London-based company that manages the vessel.

item.title: Biden to Skip U.N. Climate Summit, White House Official Says
item.description: He has attended the past two summits and calls climate change “the ultimate threat” but will miss the talks that are set to begin in Dubai on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Senior White House aides have said the president has been consumed by trying to secure a pause in the war between Israel and Hamas and release of hostages held by Hamas.

item.title: As Hamas Releases More Hostages, Longer Cease-Fire Appears Possible
item.description: A third group of captives released from Gaza included a 4-year-old dual American-Israeli citizen whose parents were killed in the Hamas attack on Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Isabel Kershner and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: People waving to Aviva Adrienne Siegel, a released hostage, aboard a bus in Ofakim, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Pro-Cease-fire Activists Shut Down Manhattan Bridge for Hours
item.description: Hundreds of protesters from Jewish Voice for Peace blocked the Manhattan entrance to the bridge, tying up traffic to and from Brooklyn.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius and Liset Cruz
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators blocked the Manhattan entrance of the Manhattan Bridge on Sunday as part of an action organized by Jewish Voice for Peace, which favors a lasting cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.

item.title: Vermont Police Arrest Suspect in Shooting of 3 Palestinian Students
item.description: The three college students were on their way to dinner on Saturday night when the shooting occurred.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Amanda Holpuch and Rebecca Carballo

item.title: Palestinian Father Welcomes His Imprisoned Son Back Home in the West Bank
item.description: A Palestinian prisoner freed on Sunday was paraded around his neighborhood in a 15-car motorcade after reuniting with relatives.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Released Palestinian prisoners react from inside a vehicle after leaving Ofer military prison on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: A 3rd Hamas-Israel Exchange
item.description: Plus an unusual mental health plan in Africa.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Avigail Idan, 4, was released from Gaza yesterday.

item.title: After 4-Year-Old American Girl Is Freed by Hamas, Her Family Breathes Sigh of Relief
item.description: Avigail Idan, a dual citizen of Israel and the United States, spent her fourth birthday as a captive after her parents were murdered in the Oct. 7 attack.
item.dc:creator: Anna Betts and Katherine Rosman

item.title: Here’s What We Know About the Israeli Hostages Released on Sunday
item.description: The group included several children, including a 4-year-old Israeli-American girl, and a Russian-Israeli who is the first man to be released.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Nadav Gavrielov and Katherine Rosman
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times

item.title: Prime Minister Netanyahu Visits Israeli Troops in Gaza
item.description: On the third day of a pause in fighting that was expected to continue until Tuesday, Mr. Netanyahu vowed to fight on “until victory.”
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A photo released by the Israeli government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during a visit to the Gaza Strip on Sunday.

item.title: American Girl Among Hostages Released on Sunday, Biden Says
item.description: “Thank God she’s home,” the president told reporters as he vowed to press for the release of more captives and an extension of the pause in fighting.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: President Joe Biden speaking in Nantucket, Mass., on Sunday.

item.title: An Oratorio About Shanghai’s Jews Opens in China at a Difficult Time
item.description: “Émigré,” about Jews who fled Nazi Germany, debuts amid U.S.-China tensions and cultural rifts over the Israel-Hamas war. It comes to New York in February.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Long Yu leads the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra in a rehearsal of “Émigré,” an oratorio about Jewish refugees who fled Nazi Germany for Shanghai, featuring the soprano Zhang Meigui, left, and the mezzo-soprano Zhu Huiling, right.

item.title: Freed Israeli Hostages Tell Relatives of Their Time in Captivity
item.description: Two days after the first batch of hostages was released, relatives who have spoken or met with them said they seemed to have been totally cut off from the outside world.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hostages released by Hamas were brought to Sheba Medical Center near Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: American Hostage Might Be Released on Sunday, Jake Sullivan Says
item.description: Jake Sullivan, the White House national security adviser, said there was “reason to believe” an American would be among the next Hamas captives freed in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Pro-Israeli demonstration near Central Park in New York this month.
